document.text: zone.  i 4 . Raider Coach Howard Clabough put- his second and third units ip the gamp  during the second half, following the  Raiders final score, a 35-yard run b y ! Patterson in the third quarter. Forest j scored twice on the Raider reserves in  the fourth period, for their 16 points in 1 the 48-16 Appomattox win. ! McCoy carried the ball three times  for 29 yards against Forest. and. Patterson had five carries for 96 yards. Fanney had 15 yards on five carries, , Motley had right yards oUutwo carries, and Chip Heraeall had four yards on two carries. The defense was led by Kettw Fanney, Keith Robinson, Daryl Hurt Gary Scruggs, Barry Phelps, Andre McCoy, Dwayne Patterson and Calvin Ligon, according to Coach Clabough,  It was one of those days when urn were playing very well, and the other team had a bad game, commented Clabough after the game.  Tomorrow Thursday, the jmrveei will square off against Brookville ai home. The Brookville game is alwayp a tough one for us, noted Clabough, The game will be played at Bragrii Stadium in Appomattox. Game time ifc 6 p.m. ?

document.text: Zack Elliott Cheatham, 82, of Evergreen hid Tuesday, July 4,19TB in Medferi Care Center inIA 6 hhucg HI Bora in Appomattox County, he was a son of the late James Hudson, and MoUy Evans Chetttham. R t v u a farmer and dealer in cattle and horses and member of the Virginia Horse Show Association. He is survived by his wife, Mayme Chocklett Cheatham a son, James Elliott Cheatham of Clearwater, Fla. a daughter, Jeanne C. Stanley of Appomat tox two sisters, Annie C. Bingham of Lynchburg and Alice C. Babcock of Columbia. S.C. four grandchildren, Zack and Nan Cheatham of Clear water, Fla., and Bill and Jan Stanley of Appomattox, and a great-grandson, James Hudson Cheatham of Clearwater, Fla. Besides the immediate fam ily, there were present a niece, Mrs. Anne Branmgan. and husband from California a nephew. Cecil Robbins, and wife from Wilmington, N. O. and a nephew, Huck Babcock, from Columbia, S. C. and many cousins. Funeral services were con ducted at 130 p.m. Friday from Robinson Funeral Home m Appomattox. Burial was m Evergreen Cemetery. Serving as pall bearers were Jack Baker, David Paulette, Kermit Paulette, Edward Har vey, Leslie Goodrich, Jesse Franklin, Herbert Diadmond, and Henry Simmons.

Fnrbush out, de  molishing the carriage, which was driven by a colored man. The 00 cupants were Slightly injured.

document.text: Yes, I ship a good many, said Evans. Why do you ask? T v e just had all my white Leg horns stolenforty of them. Every one round here is losing chickens. Now those chickens have to be mar keted somewhereand not around here. Its fifty miles to the city, which is the safest place to m arket them. If I stole chickens, Id freight them down, dressed and packed in barrels. So I thought if anybody round here was doing the thieving and the thieves, whoever they are, take the local paper, and certainly do know this part of the county as well as their hand  I m ight get some hint from your shipments. Thats a first rate idea, said the young man. But I dont remember any special shipper of dressed poul try in barrels. The W alter boys pack that way, but I guess were not sus pecting them! Mrs. Dixon sends a barrel now and then. So do the peo ple on the Lawrence farm th ats been an experimental poultry farm for the last year. I hear they report they lost badly through a raid by the thieves two months ago. The Elliotts, over at Orwell, send dressed poultry, too, but never very much. It doesnt seem------- .No, it doesnt, said Dorothy, looking perplexed. But these chick ens have got to get to market, Frank, somehow. Ive started to hunt this county over till I find whats become of them. I guess Id better drive to the other stations up and down the road. Theyd be likely to choose a stupid agent to ship through, so I dnt wonder they keep away from here. Then she flushed a t having paid Frank a compliment, and Frank flushed, too, with pleasure, for he knew that his pretty schoolmate never said things unless she meant them. It p u t him on his mettle. But see here, Dorothy, why do you have to drive up and down the road? W hats the m atter with my telegraphing instead? Come in and sit down, and I ll get you all the in formation you want in half an hour. So Dorothy sat and listened to the clicking w.ires, and took some brief notes on a telegraph pad that Frank pushed over to her across the table. Wagner, at Dorrance station, says that the Lawrence farm sends a bar rel now and then and a crate occa sionally. The Widow Ransom is the heaviest shipper sends both crates and barrels. Jones, at Pond station, says Hank Janeway ships a barrel sometimes so does the Lawrence farm. The Browns send a crate now and then white Leghorns and Ply mouth Rocks. Collins, at Pelham Junction, says that Mrs. Robinson ships more than anybody else, but Jim Henry sends a barrel or a crate now and then, and so does the Law rence peoplePlymouth Rocks, most ly. King, at Bellevue station, says everybody sends in crates, except a barrel now and then from the Law rence people and Sally W alker. Frank leaned back and whistled softly. Dorothy smiled and pushed the telegraph pad under his eyes. Five underlinings marked the name Lawrence repeated in each of the five reports from Milby, Dorrance, Pond, Pelham and Bellevue. You clever girl! said Frank. Youve got hold of the right end. No honest poultry farm ever shipped that much to the city, and through five different stations in small lots. But supposing its so, how are we go ing to prove it? The man doesnt live who can identify an ordinary white Leghorn hen or Plymouth Rock pul let. But the girl does! cried Dorothy, triumphantly. Since day before yesterday I can pick out any one of my forty Leghorns with absolute cer tainty, Frank. I I dipped their legs, every one of them, in a fast black that wont come off, so that I could know them again if they were stolen. Frank Evans lay back in his chair and laughed delightedly. Dorothy, you always were at the head of the class, he said, heartily. But what are you going to do now? Im going to the Lawrence farm , said Dorothy, unfastening the hitch ing strap. You mustnt do that. They might do you an injury. W ait till I can get a constable and a search warrant. You m ustnt go alone, Dorothy. , I wont have it. I dont mind a search w arrant, said Dorothy, with composure. That is what I brought this for. She pulled out the mysterious box, and disclosed various brightly labeled bottles and packages. I am Miss Jane Smith, Frank, agent for these poultry remedies, which I am driv ing about the county introducing among intelligent poultry farmers. I shall get into the Lawrence chicken yards, and come away again without any trouble, thank you. But I should like the constable to be at the end of the lane, ready to come in a little later. Ill get Dick Williams to tend the station, said Frank, and drive over with you p u t the constables and

text.snippet: Junction, says that Mrs. <mark>Robinson</mark> ships more than anybody

highlights.snippet: Junction, says that Mrs. <mark>Robinson</mark> ships more than anybody

document.text: years, and at Madison Heights. He has pioneered in the field of religious drama, and is an author of many books of hyms and no velty songs as well as religious drama. Rev. Emurian is quite a popu lar after - dinner speaker all over the country and the Appo mattox Lions were most fortu nate to have Mm here. Rev. Emurian himself is a. member of toe Lions International. Prior to Rev. Emurians talk, the new officers of the Lions Club were installed by Seibert Myers from Lynchburg. They are as follows president, Ivey Holland 1st vice pres., W. W. Blythe 2nd vice pres., Rihcard D. Robinson 3rd vice pres., W. C. Dudley lion tamer, Jim Beamer tail twister, Raymond Jamerson and Muriel Jamerson, secretary - treasurer. Dinner was served by the W. Rev. Emurian is paster of  S.C.S. of Memorial Methodist Cherrydale Methodist Church  Church, who will use the money and is serving his second year raised from this dinner to help there, having previously held pay for the shrubbery on the pastorates in Portsmouth for 15 church grounds.

document.text: Years ago the late Rev. H, Frederick Jones, while pastor at Liberty Baptist Church, gave me a small book entitled, What Every W riter Should Know. Packed with practical informa tion about grammar, style, punctuation, spelling, etc. Ex ample counties with same names but different spelling. There is Allegany county in M aryland and New. York, Alleghany in North Carolina andTfrginia, and Allegheny in Pennsylvania, Bulloch county in Georgia, Bullock in Alabama. Burnet in Texas, Burnett in Wisconsin. Clarke county in Alabama, Georgia, Iowa, Mis sissippi, Virginia and Washing ton, but elsewhere it is Clark. Dickenson county in Virginia. Piçkinson county in Michigan.  Green county in Kentucky and Wisconsin all others, including Virginia, it is Greene. Ix u isa county in Virginia. Smyth county in Virginia all others Smith. Same for county names npt found in Virginia. Davidson county in North Carolina and Tennessee Davison county in North Dakota. Coffee county in Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee Guffey in Kansas. Cook in minois and Minnesota Cooke in Texas. Stanley county in South D akota Stanly in N orth égrolina. Stark in Illinois, tferth Dakota and Ohio Stark jft-Indiana. Storey in Nevada Story in Iowa. Andrew in - Maine Andrews in Texas. Barber in Kansas Barbour ip  Ajahema and West Virginia. Plus many others. It took a long time to got agreement da how fo spell Appomattox. I have found ft advisable to get the correct spelling of names as toon as convenient meeting someone. John Smith may ipU his name J ob Sipythe. Sally may Pww spell her name Sallye may be BQlye Jo. I ,tto privilege of peÇg yom- name any way you deore. w  I nice to know. Loyd and Bara Vaughn, or Lloyd ip4 Varan Vaughan. My U nameis Robinson, h títere are fine folks named JWértaon, sob. Robson. 8ome change muñes. When 1 mit Brightleaf, her ! wo Fsttesoo. not POterson. hut to mah tt to Robinson. Thanks  raiding, and seeya

document.text: y The A.C.H.S. Varsity Foot ball season is over, the joy and Satisfaction of winning, the ting of defeat, the recognition, he banquet and the awards. For the many hours of dedication and hard work from Hie coaching staff, thank you! jSbach Robinson and his staff have done a fine job with our earn. They have taught the game well, and taught that fmotion is no substitute for pkill and good sportsmanship. Each member of the team has had the training and opportun ity to develop his potential jddlls, then to use those skills In a team effort.  Coaches Robinson, Blanton and Morris not only deserve Recognition as good coaches on he field but also as outstanding tnen who have helped our youth develop positive attitu d es, self-dicipline, and character. These traits enhance academic achievement and are a valuable gsset throughout life.- i I consider my son fortunate to have played under these dedicated and capable men. Sincerely Anne L. Ramsej

document.text: y Parade chairman. Mrs. Louise Lawson reports that approxi mately 40 units will make up the parade preceding the Miss Ap pomattox Pageant on Saturday. April 3. The parade will begin promptly at 3 p m. from in front of Robinson Funeral Home. The parade route will follow Court Street to the intersection of Main down Main Street to Church Street to the intersecion of High land Ave. and then left on High land Ave. and disband. Included in the parade will be the Marine Color Guard from Lynchburg. Appomattox High and Carver- Pnce High School Bands. Miss Buckingham and the Miss Buck-

document.text: X Mr. Gilbert Allen a valued citizen living near Curdsville is much improved in health under-the cure of Dr. Crute, of Farmvillf- Mr. and Mrs. Cabell Robinson and Miss MarjteSimpson add much to the social enjoy men of the village at Bujkiughanj Mr. R. L. G iilespieyuns l miles a day carrying the m ul which is too m uch tdx on any one man and 1 told him so. Mr. Arthur Armstrong, of Farmville, was here on busi ness on Saturday the 12 th. 1 was at Dillwyn Saturday and my attention was called to the immense quantity of tim ber Mr. H M. White has oa his lumber yard. Miss M aggie Gaines is a guest at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Clay near Bucking ham and she is in quite feeble health. Mrs. Grace Boatwright .a clerk of the county school board here is prompt andeffi cient also as an officer. Mrs. R. F. Eldridge has been doing some good work for the treasurer of the county in mak ing off the tax tickets. If the tax payers of the coun ty are opposed to a bond issue they should let Mr. Boatwright and Mr. Ferguson know it. The sale of tobacoo on the Lynchburg market at the auc tion warehouses amounted to about 41 million pounds up to Christmas and the prices seem to be as good as those elsewhere. The low grade of lags seem not wanted on any of the markets. Mr. Williams told the people on the Farmville market that 80 of the tobacoo pledged to the association market had already found buyers at satisfactory prioes.  Competition is the life of trade and it is good to have more tbuu one kind of market.

document.text: WYTHEVILLE SCOUTS TO CAMP AT APPOMATTOX Mayor Richard D. Robinson an nounced today that a group of dyer 20 Boy Scouts from Wythe- ville, Va., would come to Appo mattox Friday, August 17, for a week-end camp at Old Appo mattox Court House. Arrange ments have been made for the visiting Scouts to encamp on his toric land at the battleground area and take their hikes over Civil War trails. Paul W. Walk, Assistant Scoutmaster, Wythe- ville, will accompany the, Scouts to Appomattox and supervise their activities. He will get a helping hand from Chares R. Thomas, of the local Lions Club committee which sponsors the Boy Scouts here. Mr. Thomas stated this morning that he hopes to arrange for Appo mattox Scouts to cooperate in this visitation.

Va., Mrs. Betty Lou Hudson and Mrs. June Ann Wills of Appomattox two brothers, G. R. Wright of Ap pomattox, Floyd C. Wright of Lynchburg, and Johnny Wright of Perry Pt., Md. four sisters, Mrs. Juanita W. Slnith of Ashland, Mrs. Bessie W. Harding and Mrs. Violet W. Parker of Lynchburg, and Mrs. Nannie W. Seay of Appomat tox, and nine grandchildren. Funeral services will be con ducted at 2 p.m. Thursday at Robinson Funeral Home by the Rev. L. A. Trent. Burial will be in Liberty Cemetery. The family is at the re sidence.

Through the cooperation of Jerry Robinson, Athletic Direc tor at ACHS, and his staff, the game football has again been donated to the Appomattox County Rescue Squad to be used in an effort to raise money for their Canteen Fund which is nearing a zero balance. Money for the Canteen Fund is made by members of the rescue squad by sponsoring projects and is used for the annual installation of officers dinner, for kitchen supplies, for flowers for hospitalized members and for several other needs not financed through donations to the General Fund. document.text: Would you like the Home coming Football  game baU for a keepsake or to have it to do with whatever you so desire? It could be yours! Through the co-operation of head coach, Jerry Robinson, and his staff, the  game ball has been donated to the Appo mattox County Rescue Squad to be used in an effort to raise funds for their Canteen Fund which is completely down to a zero balance. F r i d a y , November 5th, is H o m e c o m i n g at Appomattox County High School. Festivities begin with a parade in the after noon, followed by the kick-off of its Homecoming Football game at Bragg Stadium at 8 p. m. when the mighty Raiders take on a strong team from Altavis ta High School and ending with a Homecoming Dance in the Gym from 10 to 12 p.m. spon sored by the senior class. By 700 p.m., members of the Appomattox County R e s c u e Squad wiU be stationed inside the gate and throughout the stadium offering chances on the  game ball for a donation of 25Ç each or 5 chances for one dollar. All three of the Rescue Squad vehicles will be partici pating in the parade and will be on stand-by throughout the game and tickets can be obtained at any of the three vehicles. In cidents, if you have not seen the new SWAB Ambulance, you are invited to do so Friday night. Money for the ACRS Canteen Fund has, in the past, been earn ed by the members of the Squad by having bake sales, selling food at Auction Sales and vari ous other money making pro jects. Money from this Fund is used for kitchen supplies coffee and such, for flowers or gifts sent to hospitalized crew mem bers, for a dinner once a year for the members at the Installa tion of Officers meeting and for several needed items not bought with money from the General Fund. Your support in this pro ject will be appreciated. Thanks to Coach Robinson and all those at Appomattox County High School who have made this possible. Bring with you some extra change . . . who knows, you may be the lucky one who takes home the prized  game ball . Drawing will take place just after the half-time activi ties.

document.text: would- rather die a thousand deaths. But there was a spirit of reuniting. After the hour-long meeting, Union artillerymen started a 100-gun salute in celebration, but Grant ordered it stopped. The terms bad been generous. Rebel soldiers had been allowed to keep their horses and mules and go home officers kept their side arms. The town has moved three miles away from its 1865 site since then, to gather around the railroad station, now an arts and crafts center. Across the street is Jeanne Stanleys restaurant, where are served charcoaled steaks, hospitality and cheerful tales about her last vacation to Thailand and Japan. On the edge of town a new furniture plant is paying passing good wages, along with the Appomattox Garment Co. and the gas pipeline pumping station. Appomattox is still a friendly little country village that can hardly be called industrialized, but on its own terms it has a newly industrial life. It has been, says Calvin Robinson, Appomattox histor ian and enthusiast,an induce ment for our brightest and most promising young people to stay here rather than migrate to the cities. It has brought good jobs, a better living standard, nicer homes, and development away from our former dependence on

text.snippet: has been, says Calvin <mark>Robinson</mark>, Appomattox histor ian and

highlights.snippet: has been, says Calvin <mark>Robinson</mark>, Appomattox histor ian and

document.text: working toward, says Hesson. Staffing needs of the emotionally disturbed students are determined by the severity of the students problems. At the secondary level it is possible for the teacher to work alone with students. At the Appomattox Elementary Sc hool the needs of the students now are such that a teacher and two aids are necessary. In the local school division, teachers of the emotionally disturbed hold masters degrees endorsing their ability to teach and handle the emotionally disturbed. The Appxnhattox Elementary School program for thè emotionally disturbed is financ ed by allocation of federal funds received from submitting an application for competitive money, in additon to state and local funds. F ather Darkleaf By CALVIN ROBINSON With Easter behind us, next special days include May Day, Mothers Day and Memorial Day. Easter week  end was quiet around town, and mostly an occasion for family gatherings. Church attendance was at or near record and the weatherman was in a good mood. Now it is cooler and several have asked what happened to Spring. Time remains to get a garden started. I have one dogwood and it is in bloom, a white one. Greatest joy is a blooming azalea garden. Best I have seen is . pt tbe Robinson Funeral Home. And one other Hem. 1 was visited by The Easter Bunny. Ah yes, I was in My Den and looked out the window towards the garden spot, and there was a rabbit hopping about and enjoying the scenery. A one-rabbit

document.text: Woodrow Wilson Fleshman, 62, of Rt. 1, Appomattox died at 1210 a.m. on Tuesday, Novem ber 23, 1976 at the Virginia Baptist Hospital. He was the husband of Mrs. Agnes Ranson Fleshman. Born in Charlotte County, he was the son of the late Samuel Crother Fleshman and Mary Virginia Rogers Fleshman. He was a retired merchant, a former school bus driver for the Appomattox County School System for 20 years, and a member of Rocks Baptist Church. In addition to his wife, he is survived by three sons, Wilson K. Fleshman, W. Rayford Fleshman, Gary R. Fleshman, all of Appomattox two daughters, Mrs. Irma F. Phelps, Miss Debra A. Flesh man both of Appomattox two brothers, George Fleshman of Lynchburg, Harpson Fleshman of Phenix two sisters, Mrs. T. C. Woodall of Newport News, Mrs. Edward Joy of Richmond, and three grandchildren. Km ineral services will be lBqpucted at 200 P.M. pn Thursday at Rocks Baptist. Church with burial in the church cemetery. The family will be at Robinson Funeral Home from 700 until 900 p.m. on Wednesday.

document.text: Women Past 40 The woman more than 40 years old has a struggle when thrown on her own resources, reports Miss Mary V. Robinson of Washington, public information director of the Womens Bureau of Public Employ ment.  . . . Try as we may to be lieve otherwise, there is still dis crimination on jobs on the basis of sex . . .  A survey described by Miss Robinson suggests that older womenwho often have had college training before marriageare excel lent tutors for children may serve aa companions or as expert shop pers may direct parties may do fancy cooking at homes or develop job in hotels and otosj Ifljf   organisations.

document.text: Women members of the Virginia delegation to the Demo cratic National Convention entertained at a luncheon last Wednesday in honor of Virginias First Lady, Mrs. Albertis S. Harrison. Mrs. Watkins Abbitt of Appomattox, wife of the Fourth District Congressman and State Central Committee Chairman, is shown above at the head table with Mrs. John Garland Pollard, of Richmond, National Committeewoman. Also present was Mrs. Calvin Robinson, of Appomattox, al ternate delegate-at-large. The luncheon was held at historic Smithville Inn, in Absecon, New Jersey.

document.text: WM. T. COLEMAN Lynchburg, Va. Dear Mr. Robinson, Our friends and neighbors of Ap pomattox were so very nice to us after the burning of our home and since, it would be virtually impos sible to thank each for his kindness. We would appreciate it if you would acknowledge our Indebted ness to all in your paper. We plan to start rebuilding be fore spring, and our present ad dress is 118 Harrison, Street, Lynch burg, Va. Very sincerely, William T. and Anna R. Coleman.

document.text: Without showing the slighest effect of the severe ordeal through which he had gone, Herman Frank, a druggist, 1272 Broadway, appeared at his place of busi ness, despite the fact that the night be fore a cyst that had eaten into his brain and was endangering his life had been removed by the most delicate of opera tions. Frank has a slight scar over his right eye, and in a glass tube is the un broken cyst that had so long threatened his life. The sack was removed without being punctured by Dr. E. A. Robinson of 5b West Thirty-eighth street, and the patient submitted to the entire operation, lasting more than an hour, without tak ing an anaesthetic. He even sat before a mirror so placed that he could see what was going on, hoping the interest he would, take might help to ally the agony

document.text: With Virginia voters to elect a Governor, Lieutenant Governor, At torney General and members of the House of Delegates on Tuesday, Nov. 3, political interest is on the up swing here. Appeals are being made to voters by Democratic and Republi can candidates. Representative Watkins M. Ab- bitt, of Appomattox, is state chair man of the campaign for the Demo cratic nominees. George F. Abbitt Jr. is the Democratic chairman for Appomattox County, with Mrs. Cal vin Robinson co-chaifman for the ladies.

document.text: With V. 1. L. Robinson, the executive secretary, in charge of the office and directing the work of organization, perma nent headquarters of the Vir ginia Good Roads Association have just been established in Murphys Hotel. The associa tion has before it one outstand ing object  to see Virginia have an adequate system of roads properly maintained. President C. C. Vaughan, Jr., and Secretary D. B. Ryland, of the association, have just left Richmond after meeting Mr. Robinson and completing arrangements for the opening of the .office. Mr. Robinson, for five years secretary of the Dixie Highway Association, reported for ddty on August 1 He is considered an expert in highway and transportation matters and is a member of several important Federal high way committee.

document.text: With the great expectations which are placed on schools to provide effective instructional programs, the administrative- supervisory staff of the Appomattox County Public 8chools has planned a aeries of in-service sessions which will increase their proficiency in their assigned positions. It is intended that these half-day meetings will cover the topics of Planning and Management, Coordination and Communica tion, School Law, Personnel Evaluation, and Curriculum Development. They will be attended by principals, assist ant principals, superintendent and supervisors. The first sesaion was conducted by Dale Robinson, Director of Planning, State Department of Education, who met with the group on August 11 to discuss planning and management as it relates to the  successful performance of ad ministrative and supervisory responsibilities in carrying out the school divisions program of instruction. Dr. E. B. Howerton, Jr., recently appointed Assistant Superintendent in the 8tate Departm ent of Education, conducted the session on August 20 which was in regard to school law. His discussion included management of the students school records and the law as it relatas to the individual teacher, school, and division. He stated that educations three obligated responsibilities for the safety and wall being of students are to provide proper prior jnMMf-rier far any activity, to Jtoperly supervise, and to maintain the school as a safe plaça. Ho discussed due process procedures as they relate to suspension. The intent of a recent legislation has been to protect the righto of students and to establish a framework for effective punishment to bo carried out in situations in which disciplinary action is dictated. The three remaining ses sions, Coordination and Com munication, Personnel Evalua tion, and Curriculum Develop ment will be coordinated through the University of Virginia School of Education. Persona who conduct these workshops will be provided by the university and will repre sent persons who are recogniz ed as specialists in the remaining areas to be covered.

text.snippet: was conducted by Dale <mark>Robinson</mark>, Director of Planning, State

highlights.snippet: was conducted by Dale <mark>Robinson</mark>, Director of Planning, State

document.text: With the exception of Ivey Hol land, chairman of the Finance Committee, there are strong in dications that five out of the six Town Councilmen of Appomat tox will seek re - election. Holland last week stated em phatically that he will not seek election again. The others Mrs. Calvin Robinson, Burke Guill, Randolph Gilbert, Henry Pack, and Lewis McDearmon, are eith er uncommitteed at this time, or have stated that they are con sidering running again. Mayor Lawson Dr. S. R. Lawson, town mayor, says that a number of people have asked him to run again, and that he is seriously con sidering it.

document.text: With successful regular-season records under their belts, the boys and girls track teams at Appomat tox County High School were preparing this week for the Seminole District meet, scheduled for today Thursday at Altavista, starting at 2 p.m. The boys team, which compiled a 44 record this season, has been led by Charles Walker. Jeff Fanney, and Malcolm Miller, according to track coach Ray Archer. In the district meet. Walker will compete in the long jump, triple jump, 400-meter fun, 800-meter run, and mile relay. Fanney will participate in the 300-meter hurdles, 880 relay, and mile relay. Miller will compete in the 1600-meter run and the mile relay. Others who will compete today include Tim Williams pole vault, Todd Scruggs shot put, mile relay, Tommy Robinson discus, and Pete Baldwin 300-meter run. Toby Cunningham, Tommy Rich ardson, and Lewis Napier will also travel with the team to Altavista as relay t eam members and alternates. Thelgirfiftif4ht, which compiled 1 4-2 record this season, was led by RubyBmith, Yolanda Trent, Terry Moore. Lynn Robinson, and Rhonda Morgan, according to the coach. Smith will compete in the long jump, high jump. 100-meter hurdles, 400-meter run, and 880 relay. Trent will participate in the 100-meter dash, the 880 relay, and the 440 relay. Moore will run the 200-meter dash, the mile relay, and the 880 relay. Robinson will run in the 800-meter run and the 1600-meter run. Morgan will participate in the 440, 880 and mile relays. Other girls who will compete today include Corrine Hubbard shot put, mile relay, Carolyn Carnefix 3200-meter run, Janet Smith will run in the 400 and 880 relays, Fontella Robinson will run in the 880 and mile relays, and April Archer and Flo Fieshman will run in relays for the team. Overall were real pleased with the season, commented Coach Archer this week. The girls and boys teams carried approximately 30 athletes each, and many of them will return to compete again next season, according to the coach. Weve only had one decent day this season to run a track meet, the coach said. Its been a bad year, weather-wise, for trade. But the

highlights.snippet: put, mile relay, Tommy <mark>Robinson</mark> discus, and Pete Baldwin

document.text: With school starting soon, Appomattox Boy Scout Troop 546 took advantage of the last few days of summer for a campingfishing trip. Camping along a scenic curve in the James River on the Al Carmody Farm in Buckingham County, 13 scouts and adult scouters got fishing lines wet. Canoeing, camping and cooking skills were well utilized by the scouts. Nine scouts, Roy Brennen, Toby Brennen. Roger Steinkamp, Bently Nash, Edwardo Gar da. Dennis Reynolds, Chris Robinson, Luis Robinson, and Mike Carmody were joined by adult leaders Allen Harville and Al Carmody along with Selmon Robin son. A rain shower diidnt stop the good time as the scouts crawled into their tents after a meal of fresh fish and a Dutch oven cobbler cooked over ah opeit fire. A court of honor was held August 17 t award Prog ress Awards. Six boys, Roy Brennen, Roger Steinkamp, Luis Robinson, Chris Robin son, Edwardo Garda and

document.text: with power Its duty would be to en- force all laws To one who for twenty-fiveyears has uniformly supported measures for prohibition, it has been disappointing to note jhe methods and agencies em- ployed by.the Republican party in the enforcement of the national prohibi tion - laws, Senator Robinson con tinued. , He said the question should b treated as moral and economic rather than political and that many defining to be reformers have clouded the sub ject with confusion and misunder standing. These people, he said, have discredited the motives of those who display moderation and fairness in the discussions on the subject and of those who are dissatisfied with pres ent conditions. President Wilson vetoed the Vol stead Act, said Senator Robinson. The Integrity of his panose was not questioned his good faith was gener ally conceded. Senator Robinson then referred to Governor Smiths telegram to the Houston convention in which he pledged himself to enforce prohibition to the limit of my ability without reservation or evasion. This language ta an unqualified acceptance of the obligation to en force the law to the best of his abil ity, deolred Senator Robinson- The vice-presidential nominee point- ed out that the enforcement of pro hibition under the last two Repub lican administrations has been under the Treasury Department, whose head, prior to national prohibition was largely interested In the liquor business. He referred to the feet that Senator-elect William 8. Vara of Pennsylvania, whose action In swing ing to Mr. Hoover at Kansas City was largely responsible for the nomination of the Republican candidate was elected on a. platform containing a single plank, the repeal of national prohibition. Can It be said that because Gover nor Smith believes that, without re

text.snippet: prohibi tion - laws, Senator <mark>Robinson</mark> con tinued. , He said

document.text: With nearly every eligile voter casting a ballot Tuesday, citizens of the Town of Appomattox named ane automobile dealer, Charles T. Mioses, Jr., as Mayor and another automobile dealer, John S. Ginels as top winner for the six-member Town Council. The Times-Virginian unofficial talley sheet showed Moses ahead, by a dose margin of 220 votes for Mayor to 216 for incumbent Richard D. Robinson. This was the closest race for Mayor here in many years. The ally sheet showed the fol lowing results for Council, with, the top six elected John S. G rin d s ....................... 280 C, Lewis McDeanmon ........... 266 John C, Caldwell . . . . . . . . 261 Grover E. Smith 230 T. Hunter Dickerson . . . . 2215 Clarence C. Poe ................... 269 Mrs. Calvin Roibineon . . . . 206 Ivey Holland ....................... 169 Grover P. Beasley Jr .............. 139 B. H. Guill ........................... 120 J, T. Almond ....................... 11.0 S. J. Evans .......................  . 109 J. T. Irby ................................ 95 The new town officials will take office in September, and serve for a term of two years. The Mayor-elect, Charles Thomas Closes, Jr., is the son of State Sen ator and Mrs. Ohas. T. Moses, of Appomattox. He was born in Appo mattox in August of 1922. He grad uated from Appomattox High School in 1946 and entered Virginia Mili tary Institute in that fall, where he studied until May 1943, when he entered the United States Army as a private. A red letter day in bis life was May 22, 1943, the day on which he received hie War Diploma from Vir ginia Military Institute enlisted .in the U. S. Army and was married to Mies Ruby Martin, the daughter of Mrs. E, B. Martin and the late Mr. Martin, of Oakville. While in the Army, he attained the rank of First Lieutenant in the Combat Engineers. After serving approximately 3 yearn in the mili tary service, inchidingbatii the European and Pacific Theaters, he returned to Appomattox, where he began his business career with the Moses Motor Company, he Chevro let and Oldsmobile Dealership own ed and operated by his father and grandfather, C. T. and T. W. Moses. Charles Thomas and Ruby are the proud parents of three daughters, Joan, Janet and Linda Jo, and an infant son, Charles Thomas, HI, All of the Moses family are mem bers of Memorial Methodist Church, where Charles IteomaD it  member of he Official Board  Charge Lay Leader and a Sunday School teach er. Since his return to Appomattox in 1646, he has been very much in terested -in the .civic affairs of the community. He  helped organize the National Guard Unit at Appomattox and served as its Commanding Of ficer for three years. He has been quite active in the American Le gion, having served aa Commander of the Post 164 for two years, has served as Fourth District Oratorical Chairman for the Legion Depart ment of Virginia, and is a member of the 46  8 Voiture 1133. He is a member and Past Presi dent of the Appomattox Parent- Teacher Association, and is a mem ber of the Appomattox Lions Club. He is a member of the Board of Directors of the Farmers National Bank, and previously served for 3 terms as a member of the Town Council.

text.snippet: for incumbent Richard D. <mark>Robinson</mark>. This was the closest

document.text: with Mrs. Bryants mother, Mrs. Martin. Mrs. Harry Ferguson and Her bert visited with relatives in Buckingham Sunday. Mrs. Phebe Heath, Washington and Everette, of Buckingham, visited Mrs. Heaths daughter, Mrs. Florence Amos, Sunday night. New Hope Baptist Church had its baptismal service Sunday night. Bobby Garrett, Wayne Fergu son and Herbert Ferguson at tended the Richmond Fair Sat urday. Let your light so shine before men that they may see your good works, and glrify your Father which is in heaven. Mathew 516 Mrs. T. C. Harvey was dinner guest in the home of Mrs. Lester B. Harvey Thursday. Mrs. Peggy and Don visited in the home of Mr. and Mrs. T. C. Harvey Tuesday. Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Robinson and Robbie spent the week end in the home of Mr. and Mrs. T. C. Harvey. Mr. and Mrs. Charlie Harvey,

text.snippet: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph <mark>Robinson</mark> and Robbie spent the

highlights.snippet: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph <mark>Robinson</mark> and Robbie spent the

document.text: with hot hands, who burned 12. David Read was high scorer for Jefferson Forest as he shot 20 points. Waldo Freeman, for Forest, shot 12 and Arthur Read, 10. Appomattox shot 50 from the court and held Forest to 40. Robinson, with 30 seconds left to go, scored to bag the win 57-55 over Forest. The Raiders have found the mental factor in winning and with the talent on the Squad, should have a better second half season than the first.
